lessons.title: Making 10: A Super Strategy for Addition! üéØ
lessons.description: Learn one of the coolest tricks for adding numbers - Making 10! Use complements and splitting to solve addition problems faster.
lessons.fullDescription: Hi there, math friends! Today we're going to learn one of the coolest tricks for adding numbers: Making 10! Think about your fingers. You have 10 of them! When we add numbers, getting to 10 first makes everything easier. It's like a stepping stone that helps us jump across a river.

subLessons.title: Complements to 10 üß©
subLessons.description: Learn the pairs that make 10! Every number has a special friend that pairs with it to make exactly 10. Master the pairs: 1+9, 2+8, 3+7, 4+6, and 5+5.
subLessons.diagnosticPrompt: The student struggles with complement facts to 10. Show them how to count up from a number to 10. Remember the pairs: 1+9, 2+8, 3+7, 4+6, 5+5. Practice identifying which number is needed to make 10.
subLessons.content: What does 'complement' mean? It means 'the friend that helps you get to 10!' Every number has a special friend that pairs with it to make exactly 10. The pairs are: 1+9=10, 2+8=10, 3+7=10, 4+6=10, 5+5=10. Memory tip: If you know one pair, you know two! If 4+6=10, then 6+4=10 too!

subLessons.title: Splitting to Apply Make-10 ‚úÇÔ∏è
subLessons.description: Use the complement pairs to solve harder addition problems! Split numbers to make 10 first, then add what's left.
subLessons.diagnosticPrompt: The student can identify complements but struggles to apply them. Show them step-by-step: 1) Find what the first number needs, 2) Split the second number, 3) Make 10, 4) Add the rest. Try examples like 7+8: need 3 to make 10, split 8 into 3+5, so 7+3=10, then 10+5=15.
subLessons.content: Now that you know the pairs, let's use them to solve harder problems! When adding two numbers, we can split one number to help us make 10 first. For example, 7+8: Start with 7, ask 'what does 7 need to make 10?', the answer is 3. Split 8 into 3 and 5. Give the 3 to the 7: 7+3=10. Add what's left: 10+5=15!

items.question: What is 7 + 8 = ?
items.hint: 7 needs 3 to make 10. Split 8 into 3 and 5. So 7+3=10, then 10+5=15

items.question: What is 9 + 4 = ?
items.hint: 9 needs 1 to make 10. Split 4 into 1 and 3. So 9+1=10, then 10+3=13

items.question: What is 6 + 7 = ?
items.hint: 6 needs 4 to make 10. Split 7 into 4 and 3. So 6+4=10, then 10+3=13

lessons.title: Doubles & Near-Doubles
lessons.description: Double numbers and use them to solve similar problems

subLessons.title: Doubles Facts
subLessons.diagnosticPrompt: The student forgot their doubles facts. Practice with visual manipulatives.

subLessons.title: Near-Doubles
subLessons.diagnosticPrompt: The student doesn't see the connection to doubles. Show them: 6+7 is one more than 6+6.

lessons.title: Choosing Strategies
lessons.description: Decide which strategy works best for each problem

subLessons.title: Which Strategy Fits?
subLessons.description: Decide whether to use Make-10 or Doubles
subLessons.diagnosticPrompt: The student can do the strategies but doesn't know when to use each one. Help them decide based on the numbers.
